feedback.Physical object: Included — A tangible hardware assembly within the car's engine system.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Designed and manufactured entirely by humans.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — Purely mechanical/electrical in design and function.
feedback.Fixed/static: Included — Installed in a permanent position within the vehicle.
feedback.Structural: Included — Composed of interconnected housing, switches, and wiring.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — User-facing interface elements such as key slot or start button.
feedback.Material form: Included — Constructed from metal, plastic, and electronic components.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Actively engages the ignition and control circuitry.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Built to initiate the engine's start sequence.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Included — Produces ignition spark and system activation signals.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Included — Especially in modern cars with anti-theft and diagnostics.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Included — Transitions the engine and vehicle systems from 'off' to 'on'.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Included — Requires human input (turn key, press button, detect key fob).
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Functions within the broader vehicle electrical and mechanical system.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires a deliberate user action to initiate.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Critical for start, but bypassable with overrides in some systems.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Excluded — Not a representational or metaphorical device.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — Interfaces with system but not designed to transmit symbolic messages.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Executes startup conditions and safety logic.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Not abstractly modular beyond physical subcomponents.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — Does not guide behavior directly.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — No self-monitoring or conceptual tracking.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Functions instantly; not defined by time management.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — Role is consistent across vehicle contexts.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Excluded — Standardized by engineering, not semantically.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not associated with personal or social roles.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Subject to safety standards, but not an intrinsic regulatory artifact.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Excluded — Commonly taught, but not inherently educative.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — Performs the same function regardless of environment.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Well-known component of nearly all vehicles.

encoding_notes: This encoding treats the ignition system as a functional component embedded in a car's architecture. It scores strongly in the physical and functional layers due to its material presence, human interaction, and purposeful activation of electrical processes. A single abstract trait is included for its logical role in validating startup conditions. Social traits are limited to public recognizability and physical visibility.
